critique: The document pertains to the appointment of a chairman to the National Labor Relations Board and outlines some operational procedures. It is difficult to assess its stance on immigration, national security vs. civil liberties, or social inclusion, as these topics are not directly addressed. The document seems to expand federal control through the National Labor Relations Board. The mention of the National Industrial Recovery Act suggests government intervention in the economy. The appointment of a chairman doesn't inherently indicate a liberal or conservative tilt. The power dynamic between the Board and the Secretary of Labor seems balanced.
